document_title: Environmental Dependence of Competitive Fitness in Rifampin-Resistant rpoB Mutants of Bacillus subtilis
summary_full: This study investigates the competitive fitness of rifampin-resistant (Rifr) rpoB mutants of Bacillus subtilis in different environments. Historically, Rifr mutations were associated with reduced fitness, but this was often assessed in rich laboratory media. Using deep sequencing and competition assays, the researchers found that the fitness advantage of specific rpoB alleles varies significantly depending on the growth environment. In nutrient-rich LB medium, the wild-type strain dominated, while in a minimal asparagine medium (SMMAsn), a specific mutant (H482N) became dominant. Growth rate and lag time measurements in monoculture did not consistently predict competitive fitness in mixed cultures. The study highlights that antibiotic resistance can confer a fitness advantage in specific environments, even without antibiotic selection, and emphasizes the limitations of using monoculture growth rates to assess true fitness in complex environments. The findings have implications for understanding microbial adaptation and the evolution of antibiotic resistance.
key_findings: The competitive fitness of rifampin-resistant rpoB mutants in Bacillus subtilis is highly dependent on the growth environment.
In rich LB medium, wild-type B. subtilis outcompeted most rifampin-resistant mutants.
In minimal asparagine medium (SMMAsn), the rpoB H482N mutant gained a significant competitive advantage over the wild-type and other mutants.
Growth rate and lag time in monoculture are poor predictors of competitive fitness in mixed-culture environments.
A secondary mutation (I528V) in rpoB was observed to increase the fitness of an initially less fit mutant (A478D) in LB medium, though not to wild-type levels.

The S487L rpoB mutant, previously shown to utilize asparagine better, did not exhibit increased fitness in the SMMAsn medium, suggesting metabolic utilization alone does not guarantee competitive advantage.
future_research_fields: Investigating the specific gene expression changes associated with the H482N mutant in SMMAsn medium to understand the mechanism of its competitive advantage.
Exploring the role of compensatory mutations in rpoB and other genes in restoring or enhancing fitness in rifampin-resistant mutants.
Examining the fitness of these mutants in more complex, ecologically relevant environments beyond simple rich and minimal media.
Further analysis of the genomic changes in the evolved A478D+I528V strain to identify additional mutations contributing to its high fitness.

conclusions: The fitness of rifampin-resistant rpoB mutants of Bacillus subtilis is not universally reduced and can be environment-dependent, with some mutants exhibiting advantages in specific conditions. Growth rate and metabolic assays in monoculture are insufficient to predict competitive fitness in mixed populations. Compensatory mutations can arise to mitigate fitness costs associated with resistance.
impact_statement: This study demonstrates that antibiotic resistance mutations can confer environmental-specific fitness advantages, impacting our understanding of microbial evolution and the persistence of resistance in the absence of antibiotic selection.
